title: Chapter 7 bankruptcy, is it legal for a credit union to cross-collateralize after discharge. ie. hold car title b/c of crdt card
question: So, for example, if I have an auto loan with the credit union, but let another vehicle get repossessed (or say I discharge credit card debt with the same bank), can they make me pay it all back before giving me the title to the car I am still paying on? Would it make a difference if I reaffirm or choose to just pay and retain?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Reaffirmation of debt and bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Lien,Secured debt,Unsecured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Car loan,Consumer protection,Vehicle title
answers: You will need to check your loan documents. Credit unions almost always have a cross-collateralization clause in their documents, so you will probably have to reaffirm everything or nothing. If there is no such clause and they are trying to impose one post-filing, they cannot do that. See a good bankruptcy attorney in your area, and take a copy of your loan documents.

My only addition to the answers to your question is the legality of the cross collateralization agreement..is it a violation of the Consumer Protection Act? maybe an attorney in California can answer that question. As a recall, about 12 years ago or so in California a lower Bankruptcy Court ruled that it was such a violation. I am in Washington and not aware of any other court cases since.but I remember that one from California! Counsel in California? Any thoughts, cases, etc>>?? Of course, who wants to pay an attorney to litigate it? BUT, it could be used in arguing possibly to create a reaffirmation agreement in terms more favorable to you.
All credit union cross collateralize their debt accounts. The agreement occurred when you opened the credit union account, not after you filed bankruptcy. I hope this perspective helps!
Credit unions, unlike banks, can cross-default you for all debt you owe

A credit card debt is a non-priority unsecured debt. Auto loans that are secured by a lien on the vehicle are secured debts.

Based on your question, let's say you have a credit card debt and 2 auto loans with the same credit union. You file a chapter 7 case and list all three debts. You can choose whether to reaffirm one or both of the auto loans. If you decide to keep (reaffirm) one of the cars, you enter into a new agreement with the credit union, promising to make payments until the agreed-upon amount is paid.

You can decide not to reaffirm the second auto loan if you do not want the second car. Assuming that there are no problems with your filing and you complete all steps, you will get a discharge of unsecured debts including the credit card debt. The lender whose credit card debt was discharged in the chapter 7 case cannot demand payment for that debt, regardless of the existence of any (reaffirmed) secured debt. To do so would be a violation of the discharge order.

You should discuss your situation with a bankruptcy attorney before making any decisions. Good luck.
I agree with Stuart. This is very common with credit unions and you will have to review your loan documents to see if the car loan is cross-collateralized with the credit card debt (or other debt).

The answer to your question is found in your loan documents. If the CU granted you an auto loan and then you applied for a credit card there, it is not uncommon for the CU to "cross-collateralize" the CC with the auto loan. If you send me copies of your auto loan docs and CC docs I can examine them for you.
